response.answer_text: MIXED RESPONSE:No doubt some of Dylan’s verse reflects badly on his relationships with women, but if one regards the entire progress of his relationship to women, one cannot help but see the emergence of maturity.Regard the lyrics of Shelter From The Storm, a song, I believe that reflects a central experience in Dylan’s self-realization. Clearly he credits the voice of “her” with his ability to devote himself to his calling. If one considers “the storm” to be the chaos of this world that he experienced “in another lifetime”, then he was able to achieve a second world, second lifetime, thanks to a time of peace, what the old-timers called “the Halcyon Days”, in a place of “shelter from the storm”. In that mystic moment “She was standing there” in Glory. The fact that he could not remain in that state, in the presence of that human/divine being attests to the transient but unforgettable, once in a lifetime meeting with the Vessel. There is no doubt of the religious/spiritual condition of that experience. BUT “Now there's a wall between us something there's been lost/I took too much for granted, I got my signals crossed”... rare indeed are those who can REMAIN in that state. But his memory and longing will serve him a lifetime: “Well I'm living in a foreign country [back to earth, thanks a lot]but I'm bound to cross the line [we all die]Beauty walks a razor's edge someday I'll make it mine [a deeper view of beauty]If I could only turn back the clock to when God and her [God as source, “her” as the Vessel] were born"Come in," she said, "I'll give you shelter from the storm." Considering the holy praise he offers, with typical bitter-sweet Dylanesque acid, I do not see how he could possibly be sexist at this point.

That is a very personal question that would require knowing the man well. Artists sometimes write songs from the perspective of others, or from the perspective of Bob in the 60s, so you can’t cherry pick lyrics to determine how he feels about women in general, now. You also cannot judge him from media interviews, as he was notorious for messing with the media and journos. And you most certainly cannot answer this question by quoting personal relationships he had with particular partners such as Joan Baez, that’s like saying anyone who has a bad, bitter breakup is sexist, which isn’t really cool. In the answers below I can see a lot cherry picking of potentially sexist sounding lyrics. So just to even the score a little bit, what about: “The man in me will hide sometimes to keep from bein’ seen But that’s just because he doesn’t want to turn into some machine Took a woman like you To get through to the man in me” “Sara, Sara,Wherever we travel we're never apart.Sara, oh Sara,Beautiful lady, so dear to my heart” Also, look at all the feminists/female recording artists that have covered his songs: Adele - ‘Make you feel my love’Chrissie Hynde - ‘I shall be released’Norah Jones - ‘I’ll be your baby tonight’Cat Power - ‘Stuck Inside Mobile with the Memphis Blues Again’Nina Simone - ‘the Ballad of Hollis Brown’Nico - ‘I’ll keep it with mine’Tracy Chapman - ‘The times they are a changin’PJ Harvey - ‘Highway 61 revisited’Emmylou Harris - ‘Every Grain of sand’Just to name a few. Not the lineup you’d expect to cover a sexist artist’s songs. When you label someone a sexist, you’d want to have pretty conclusive evidence. After all he’s written a lot of beautiful songs that have inspired countless female artists. Since I don’t know him personally or haven’t seen any evidence that he is sexist, I’ll give him the benefit of the doubt and say NO.
